title: MOVIE VISUAL ANALYTICS
text:
1 Introduction
This project analyzes IMDB movie data downloaded directly from the public dataset.
Over the past few years, the movie world has changed a lot, streaming services took off, and then COVID turned everything upside down. People started watching films in new ways, and movies began reaching audiences across the globe like never before.
This project dives into IMDb data on theatrical and feature films to uncover what’s really happening. It explores how ratings have shifted over the decades, how audience engagement changed before, during, and after the pandemic, whether genre tastes are getting more similar worldwide, and how far films now travel to different countries. Overall, it highlights the big trends like the massive boost in global reach thanks to streaming, while showing that local preferences still hold strong.
Navigate using the sidebar to see the full analysis.

title: 2  Data
text:
2.1 Description
Our Dataset is the IMDb Non-Commercial Datasets (IMDb Datasets Page): a publicly available collection maintained by IMDb, a subsidiary of Amazon. These datasets are updated daily and distributed as compressed tab-separated value files (.tsv.gz). Each file represents a different aspect of the IMDb database, including:
IMDb compiles this information from user submissions, production companies, distributors, and verified industry sources. User-generated ratings are continuously updated as viewers submit them on the IMDb platform. [link: https://datasets.imdbws.com/]

text:
title.basics.tsv.gz: title IDs, release years, genres, runtime
title.ratings.tsv.gz: IMDb user ratings and vote counts
title.akas.tsv.gz: international title names and release regions
title.principals.tsv.gz: information about cast and crew

title: 2  Data
text:
2.2 Missing value analysis


Code
knitr::include_graphics("missingValue1.jpeg")










IDs, titles, and adult flag: completely filled, no issues.
Release year: missing for ~108k movies, so we drop them (we need the year for decades and COVID periods).
Runtime: missing for ~267k movies, we later remove anything missing or under 10 minutes.
Genres: missing for ~78k movies, we keep these (they just get skipped in genre analysis).
Ratings and votes: both missing for ~393k movies (no ratings yet), so we drop them entirely.



Code
knitr::include_graphics("missingValue2.jpeg")









Our cleaning steps: We handled missing data by removing

Movies without a release year
Movies with no ratings or votes
Movies missing runtime or with runtime < 10 minutes
Movies with fewer than 50 votes (cuts out super-noisy ones)

The result is a smaller but solid dataset of real, rated films, perfect for trustworthy insights on quality, audience trends, and global reach.

title: 3  Results: Lights, Camera, Data!
4  Conclusion
text:
Our exploration highlights several key insights:

the pandemic significantly changed how movies were produced, released, and rated, but the types of stories told remained surprisingly stable, with the dominant genres (Drama, Comedy, Action) maintaining nearly identical shares before, during, and after COVID.
Audience engagement declined sharply during the pandemic and did not fully recover, as seen in lower vote counts, reflecting a more fragmented attention landscape.
The geography of film production shifted—India rose into the top three producing regions while Great Britain dropped out.
Despite theater closures, the global reach of movies actually increased post-2020, driven by streaming platforms enabling films to release in more regions.
Thriller and Documentary genres, gained noticeable momentum during COVID.

Our analysis is limited by IMDb’s inherent biases, such as inconsistent metadata, uneven rating counts, and survivorship effects. Future work could incorporate streaming data, box-office numbers, or review text analysis to provide a richer understanding of how film production and consumption are evolving.
